event.title: 1802, two brothers-in-law from Baltimore, Maryland, Christian Deardorff and Jesse Slingluff, traveled

data.event: In 1802, two brothers-in-law from Baltimore, Maryland, Christian Deardorff and Jesse Slingluff, traveled through the area and so admired the potential quality of the land along the confluence of the Tuscarawas River and Sugar Creek that they bought 2,000 acres (8.1 km2) of land in 1806 for just over $4,600.

event.title: bought 2,000 acres (8.1 km2) of land in 1806

data.event: In 1802, two brothers-in-law from Baltimore, Maryland, Christian Deardorff and Jesse Slingluff, traveled through the area and so admired the potential quality of the land along the confluence of the Tuscarawas River and Sugar Creek that they bought 2,000 acres (8.1 km2) of land in 1806 for just over $4,600.

event.title: settled there and the following year

data.event: The brothers-in-law settled there and the following year laid out the what they hoped would become a prosperous town.

event.title: today, the local telephone book features

data.event: Even today, the local telephone book features many German last names.
